The Metaverse Has Always Been a Dystopian Idea5/23/2022

Silicon Valley CEOs keep hailing its imminent arrival as they hawk digital goods, but the metaverse was a dystopian idea from its inception.

class="article__body-components article__body-components--longform"><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>A big shift is apparently underway in Silicon Valley. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The company that operates the world’s largest and most profitable social media network will not, according to its CEO, be a social media company much longer. In an announcement that inspired a fervid wave of speculation, analysis, and mockery, Mark Zuckerberg proclaimed that Facebook is going to become a “metaverse company” instead. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Facebook will pivot from being a website that is accessed through phones and laptops, Zuckerberg says, to a next generation computing platform where the focus is on a user’s “presence,” and is accessed through VR via Facebook’s Oculus headset, or other Facebook products like Portal. “I think over the next five years or so,” Zuckerberg<a href="https://www.theverge.com/22588022/mark-zuckerberg-facebook-ceo-metaverse-interview" target="_blank"> <span>told the Verge’s Casey Newton</span></a>, “we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.”</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-top"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Elsewhere in the big tech landscape, Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoft—at the time of writing the second largest company in the world in terms of market capitalization—has been promoting his aim to build an “Enterprise Metaverse.” At a Microsoft Inspire keynote talk<a href="https://embee.co.in/blog/news-announcements-keynotes-at-microsoft-inspire/" target="_blank"> <span>back in May</span></a>, and on<a href="https://seekingalpha.com/article/4441881-microsoft-corporation-msft-ceo-satya-nadella-on-q4-2021-results-earnings-call-transcript" target="_blank"> <span>a July earnings call</span></a>, Nadella described this as “a new layer of the infrastructure stack” where “the digital and physical worlds converge.”</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>It’s not just Microsoft and Facebook. A widening swath of Silicon Valley’s investor class, cheerleading pundits, and influential founders have been hyping the so-called metaverse, too. Tim Sweeney, the CEO of Epic Games, which runs Fortnite, has for years<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/video-games/2020/04/17/fortnite-metaverse-new-internet/" target="_blank"> <span>been promoting the metaverse</span></a> as the fast-arriving future. The venture capitalist Matthew Ball<a href="https://www.matthewball.vc/all/themetaverse" target="_blank"> <span>attempted to chart its potential</span></a> and explain why it is “likely to produce trillions in value.” David Baszucki, the founder of the gaming platform Roblox, sung its praises and underlined its import in a January piece for WIRED. </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><div class="abc__article_embed" data-component="RelatedArticleBlock"><div class="vice-card vice-card--light"><div class="vice-card__content"><div class="vice-card-rubric vice-card-rubric--light vice-card__vice-card-rubric"><a class="vice-card-rubric__label vice-card-rubric__link" href="/en/section/tech">Tech</a></div><h3 class="vice-card-hed vice-card-hed--light vice-card__vice-card-hed"><a href="/en/article/n7v997/landlords-want-to-make-virtual-reality-just-as-hellish-as-real-life" class="vice-card-hed__link">Landlords Want to Make Virtual Reality Just as Hellish as Real Life</a></h3><div class="vice-card-details vice-card-details--light vice-card__vice-card-details"><div class="vice-card-details__byline">Josh Gabert-Doyon</div><time class="vice-card-details__pub-date" dateTime="2021-01-26T14:00">01.26.21</time></div></div><div class="vice-card-image vice-card__vice-card-image"><a href="/en/article/n7v997/landlords-want-to-make-virtual-reality-just-as-hellish-as-real-life" class="vice-card-image__link" tabindex="-1"><div class="vice-card-image__placeholder-image placeholder-image--16-9--sm placeholder-image--16-9--md placeholder-image--16-9--lg"><div><picture class="responsive-image lazyloader--lazy"><source media="(min-width: 1000px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><source media="(min-width: 700px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><source media="(min-width: 0px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><img class="responsive-image__img" alt=""/></picture></div></div></a></div></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“The Metaverse is arguably as big a shift in online communication as the telephone or the internet,” he wrote.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“The metaverse is a vision that spans many companies—the whole industry,” as Zuckerberg put it. “You can think about it as the successor to the mobile internet.”</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>We’ve seen this movie before, of course: a host of Silicon Valley companies uniting to embrace a new and nebulous concept, a la the Internet of Things, that sounds both adequately future-y and freshly attractive to big picture-loving investors. This has not stopped those companies from fomenting a new air of inevitability within the industry, or its advocates from trumpeting its imminent arrival. “The metaverse is coming,” one futurist <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/cathyhackl/2020/07/05/the-metaverse-is-coming--its-a-very-big-deal/?sh=28b06b14440f" target="_blank"><span>enthused in Forbes</span></a> in a widely viewed story, “and it’s a very big deal.” In fact, <a href="https://www.google.com/search?q=the+metaverse+is+coming&rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS962&oq=the+metaverse+is+coming&aqs=chrome..69i57j0i22i30l2j69i64j69i60l3.3559j1j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8" target="_blank"><span>a quick Google search</span></a> reveals that everyone from <a href="https://www.wired.co.uk/article/metaverse" target="_blank"><span>WIRED</span></a> to <a href="https://www.economist.com/technology-quarterly/2020/10/01/the-metaverse-is-coming" target="_blank"><span>the Economist</span></a> to <a href="https://time.com/5955412/artificial-intelligence-nvidia-jensen-huang/#:~:text=and%20Physical%20Worlds-,The%20Metaverse%20Is%20Coming.,of%20Virtual%20and%20Physical%20Worlds&text=This%20is%20already%20playing%20out,work%20by%20Nvidia%20and%20others." target="_blank"><span>TIME Magazine</span></a> to <a href="https://investorplace.com/2021/04/the-metaverse-is-coming/" target="_blank"><span>InvestorPlace.com</span></a> to <a href="https://www.verizon.com/about/news/5g-makes-metaverse-real" target="_blank"><span>Verizon’s “News Center</span></a>” has published stories titled “The Metaverse Is Coming,” which helps to offer a snapshot of who has an interest in its arrival. </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>If it is coming, and if it is a big deal, then surprisingly few have paused to carefully consider the actual source of the metaverse, an undertaking which seems like a good idea, especially because that source is a deeply dystopian novel about a collapsed America that is overrun by violence and poverty. The metaverse was born in Neal Stephenson’s 1992 <em>Snow Crash</em>, where it serves as entertainment and an economic underbelly to a poor, desperate nation that is literally governed by corporate franchises. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>You will see no trace of the metaverse’s origins in these strategy announcements, which so far seem to hint mostly at creating and uniting more immersive digital environments in which entertainment might be consumed and work carried out—and advertising displayed, workers surveilled, and <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/martyswant/2021/07/28/as-coca-cola-auctions-its-first-nft-more-brands-are-entering-the-metaverse/?sh=cf5d7c010510" target="_blank"><span>branded NFTs</span></a> and loot boxes sold. No trace, that is, unless maybe you read about it on your Twitter feed, where a news item about a metaverse product is likely to be sandwiched between stories about crushing health care debt or anecdotes about rampant inequality. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>So I think it is worth examining why it may be that our real-world CEOs’ next big high tech concept is sprung from an overtly dystopian context of mass poverty and violence; one where an immersive, shared 3D digital environment where anything goes offers most people’s only opportunity to escape from an intolerable reality. </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“This imaginary place is known as the Metaverse,” as Neal Stephenson wrote. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article txt-center" data-component="TextBlock"><p><em>*</em></p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The hero of <em>Snow Crash</em> is named Hiro, and he is a gig worker delivery driver who moonlights as a hacker, and lives in abject poverty in a 20x30 storage unit he shares with an alcoholic roommate. “Hiro spends a lot of time in the metaverse. It beats the shit out of the U-Stor-It.”</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The U.S. as we know it has ceased to exist, and corporate entities and organized crime control whole city-states. Workers like Hiro can be killed for taking too long to deliver a pizza, and they are driven into the metaverse underworld to find extralegal work and enough money to make ends meet. The only reasonably safe places in the physical world are heavily fortressed “burbclaves” where the wealthy reside behind batteries of guns and gated communities. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The metaverse, which users access through VR goggles, is the kind of 3D digital environment that should be familiar to most people who are aware of video games today, except that it’s massive—the majority of the metaverse’s real estate is developed along The Street, a huge virtual thoroughfare that encircles thousands of miles of its digital world—there are no rules, and there are no set objectives. Users select an avatar (Stephenson also coined the popular usage of that term, too) to represent their digital selves. A higher resolution representation costs more, thus stratifying class in the virtual world, too.</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>And what do people build in the metaverse?</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“Like any place in Reality, the Street is subject to development,” Stephenson explains. “Developers can build their own small streets feeding off of the main one. They can build buildings, parks, signs, as well as things that do not exist in Reality, such as vast hovering overhead light shows, special neighborhoods where the rules of three dimensional spacetime are ignored, and free-combat zones where people can go to hunt and kill each other.” </p></span><blockquote data-component="QuoteBlock" class="abc__quote abc__quote--pullquote"><p>“…the <em>metaverse itself</em> is a place that is addictive, violent, and an enabler of our worst impulses”</p></blockquote><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Okay! So the metaverse is for light shows, people tired of existing on the space-time continuum, and mass murder. (Come to think of it, this sounds a bit like the extant internet, or just Fortnite.)</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Finally, it should be noted that there is an entire class of people, users derisively known as gargoyles, who become so hooked on existing in the metaverse that they rig themselves to be permanently plugged-in, and are permanently disfigured in reality as a result. In the years since <em>Snow Crash</em>’s publication, gargoyles have been viewed as a prescient commentary on the pitfalls of screen addiction.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Thus, in the book from which the current metaverse craze originates, not only is our world in ruins and most people are eking out precarious lives in dire poverty, but the <em>metaverse itself</em> is a place that is addictive, violent, and an enabler of our worst impulses. </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>It’s an exceedingly dark vision, if a satiric and somewhat cartoonish one (there are also lots of swords). So it’s a little remarkable that precisely none of this is acknowledged in the paeans to the metaverse that have emerged from founders and cheerleaders over the last few weeks and years, even as the vision of computing advancing as the world falls apart becomes all the more salient.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>In the world of <em>Snow Crash</em>, the metaverse is not viewed as particularly cool—it is <em>necessary,</em> because the real world has become so unbearable. Ditto in the most famous book to update the metaverse’s architecture for our modern, pop culture-saturated era: <em>Ready Player One. </em>Its Oasis is basically the Metaverse if it were written by a neural net trained on 80s movies and 00s video games. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>That book too is set in a nearish dystopian future where desperate people are driven to escape their unpleasant lives into a vast virtual environment—it is insinuated that either the Oasis is so popular because the world is so bad, or the world is so bad because the Oasis is so popular. This is a weird nexus at which to want to build out your company’s future! And yet for a time, new recruits to Facebook’s Oculus division <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/oculus-gives-all-its-employees-ready-player-one-2016-7" target="_blank"><span>were handed copies of the book</span></a> as required reading.</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article txt-center" data-component="TextBlock"><p><em>*</em></p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Both books’ metaverses get at a common truism: there <em>is </em>something inherently dystopian in a future where humans abandon the real world in favor of an escapist and consumerist-oriented fully immersive digital one. To want to spend any serious amount of time in a metaverse, it must be made more appealing than reality, a feat which can be accomplished in one of two ways—either the world outside is already shitty enough to drive you into a glitch-prone, murder-filled alternative, or the fantasy of becoming someone else is compelling enough to consume you totally. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Both configurations are fraught. It is easy to see the metaverse making a more compelling sales pitch in the days of pandemics and wildfires and increasingly limited real-world experiences available to the non-rich. But my guess is that the reason the metaverse vision inspires founders like Zuckerberg is not, primarily, the new network of market opportunities it presents, which is certainly there—but the personal interest in fulfilling the fantasy element. Zuck has mentioned that he has been thinking about the metaverse since middle school, when he may well have read the science fiction that described it. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>It could well be that the metaverse represents to the next generation of founders what, say, space travel and off-world colonies on Mars do to the likes of Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos. It is a science fictional construct that perhaps captured their imagination at an impressionable moment in their lives—in the metaverse, you can be anyone, do anything, and vanquish foes, regardless of real-world social status or physicality. As the writer and media studies professor and video game designer <a href="https://twitter.com/ibogost/status/1420788525411209217" target="_blank"><span>Ian Bogost noted,</span></a> “The metaverse was never a fantasy about virtual reality, but just one about power.” And now that these founders have the capital and power to pursue the fantasy, that is exactly what they are doing.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>When I<a href="https://gizmodo.com/the-magic-leap-con-1829716266" target="_blank"> <span>interviewed an executive at Magic Leap in 2018</span></a>, at what was arguably the company’s peak in popularity thus far, I asked him what an ideal use case of the headset would be for him. The first thing he said was “I want the Star Wars universe in my life… I want to look up at the sky and see Tie Fighters and X-wings fighting.” The aim was pure, youth-inspired science fictional fantasy. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Of course, the broader contours of both visions will likely remain fantasies—as David Karpf<a href="https://www.wired.com/story/virtual-reality-rich-white-kid-of-technology/" target="_blank"> <span>points out in WIRED</span></a>, virtual reality, and the metaverse it presumes to enable, is a perennial “rich white kid technology” that has been around for decades, keeps failing upwards, and seems destined for novelty rather than ubiquity. And it’s worth adding that the metaverse as Zuckerberg describes it—a shared 3D space where we live and work and view advertising in an embodied internet—would be an actual nightmare if it were to be designed, built, or administered by Facebook, perhaps the most notoriously drab, misinformation-littered, and aesthetically unappealing environment on the web. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Fortunately, we do not need to fear this coming to pass in concrete terms very much, as the metaverse vision is inherently somewhat ludicrous. But even if it is, the big swing earns Zuck and co. some credulity and latitude in the press, unlocks some venture capital for third party developers, and offers a little distraction from the myriad unresolved issues that still plague its much less exciting Newsfeedverse right now. In this sense, the biggest impact of announcing intentions to pursue the metaverse is that it may win Facebook, Microsoft, and other tech giants some leeway, a chance to deflect criticisms of its conduct and policies towards the fact that they are again in the midst of major evolution, so cut them some slack, you know? Many tech companies have realized they are harder to criticize if they are <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/93wq9y/uber-sells-off-sci-fi-pipe-dreams-exploiting-human-labor-is-its-only-plan"><span>constantly evolving their ambitions and shooting for the rafters</span></a>, and a massive metaverse moonshot certainly qualifies.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>But as usual with such amorphous concepts and platform aspirations, there’s very little there. None of these luminaries, from Zuck to Nadella to <a href="https://www.facebook.com/boz/posts/10113772424752191" target="_blank"><span>Boz</span></a>, seem capable of painting a coherent vision for what their particular metaverse will look or feel like, beyond gesturing at “presence” and a collection of apps, keywords, and old science fiction tropes. It is an odd vision built from a compendium of juvenile fantasies, perceived market opportunities, and overt dystopias.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Silicon Valley is often criticized for failing to anticipate the critiques of the new technologies and ideas it lionizes, and for failing to anticipate the adverse social impacts of its products. With its aspirations to construct a metaverse, it is obliviously aspiring to develop the critique itself, direct from the source. </p></span></div></div><div class="article__longform__tags"><div In an announcement that inspired a fervid wave of speculation, analysis, and mockery, Mark Zuckerberg proclaimed that Facebook is going to become a \u0026#x201c;metaverse company\u0026#x201d; instead.\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae5d\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":2,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Facebook will pivot from being a website that is accessed through phones and laptops, Zuckerberg says, to a next generation computing platform where the focus is on a users presence, and is accessed through VR via Facebooks Oculus headset, or other Facebook products like Portal. I think over the next five years or so, Zuckerberg\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.theverge.com/22588022/mark-zuckerberg-facebook-ceo-metaverse-interview\\\"\u003e \u003cspan\u003etold the Verges Casey Newton\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":604,\"wordscount\":98,\"text\":\"Facebook will pivot from being a website that is accessed through phones and laptops, Zuckerberg says, to a next generation computing platform where the focus is on a user\u0026#x2019;s \u0026#x201c;presence,\u0026#x201d; and is accessed through VR via Facebook\u0026#x2019;s Oculus headset, or other Facebook products like Portal. \u0026#x201c;I think over the next five years or so,\u0026#x201d; Zuckerberg [told the Verge\u0026#x2019;s Casey Newton](https://www.theverge.com/22588022/mark-zuckerberg-facebook-ceo-metaverse-interview), \u0026#x201c;we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.\u0026#x201d;\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae5e\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":3,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Elsewhere in the big tech landscape, Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoftat the time of writing the second largest company in the world in terms of market capitalizationhas been promoting his aim to build an Enterprise Metaverse. At a Microsoft Inspire keynote talk\u003ca href=\\\"https://embee.co.in/blog/news-announcements-keynotes-at-microsoft-inspire/\\\"\u003e \u003cspan\u003eback in May\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and on\u003ca href=\\\"https://seekingalpha.com/article/4441881-microsoft-corporation-msft-ceo-satya-nadella-on-q4-2021-results-earnings-call-transcript\\\"\u003e \u003cspan\u003ea July earnings call\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, Nadella described this as a new layer of the infrastructure stack where the digital and physical worlds converge.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":687,\"wordscount\":109,\"text\":\"Elsewhere in the big tech landscape, Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoft\u0026#x2014;at the time of writing the second largest company in the world in terms of market capitalization\u0026#x2014;has been promoting his aim to build an \u0026#x201c;Enterprise Metaverse.\u0026#x201d; At a Microsoft Inspire keynote talk [back in May](https://embee.co.in/blog/news-announcements-keynotes-at-microsoft-inspire/), and on [a July earnings call](https://seekingalpha.com/article/4441881-microsoft-corporation-msft-ceo-satya-nadella-on-q4-2021-results-earnings-call-transcript), Nadella described this as \u0026#x201c;a new layer of the infrastructure stack\u0026#x201d; where \u0026#x201c;the digital and physical worlds converge.\u0026#x201d;\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae5f\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":4,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Its not just Microsoft and Facebook. A widening swath of Silicon Valleys investor class, cheerleading pundits, and influential founders have been hyping the so-called metaverse, too. Tim Sweeney, the CEO of Epic Games, which runs Fortnite, has for years\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/video-games/2020/04/17/fortnite-metaverse-new-internet/\\\"\u003e \u003cspan\u003ebeen promoting the metaverse\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e as the fast-arriving future. The venture capitalist Matthew Ball\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.matthewball.vc/all/themetaverse\\\"\u003e \u003cspan\u003eattempted to chart its potential\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e and explain why it is likely to produce trillions in value. David Baszucki, the founder of the gaming platform Roblox, sung its praises and underlined its import in a January piece for WIRED.\u0026nbsp;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":767,\"wordscount\":121,\"text\":\"It\u0026#x2019;s not just Microsoft and Facebook. A widening swath of Silicon Valley\u0026#x2019;s investor class, cheerleading pundits, and influential founders have been hyping the so-called metaverse, too. Tim Sweeney, the CEO of Epic Games, which runs Fortnite, has for years [been promoting the metaverse](https://www.washingtonpost.com/video-games/2020/04/17/fortnite-metaverse-new-internet/) as the fast-arriving future. The venture capitalist Matthew Ball [attempted to chart its potential](https://www.matthewball.vc/all/themetaverse) and explain why it is \u0026#x201c;likely to produce trillions in value.\u0026#x201d; David Baszucki, the founder of the gaming platform Roblox, sung its praises and underlined its import in a January piece for WIRED.\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae60\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":5,\"role\":\"article\",\"site\":\"vice\",\"locale\":\"en_us\",\"web_id\":\"n7v997\",\"display\":\"inline\",\"article_id\":\"6009f14babd6330096c4c7b3\",\"article\":{\"id\":\"6009f14babd6330096c4c7b3\",\"body\":\"\u003cp\u003eOnce a geeky thought experiment about forgoing the physical world and entering a fully-functional virtual reality, the Metaverse is now being colonized by the most unlikely industry: real estate.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn late December, Dirk Lueth watched in awe as the New York Stock Exchange building was auctioned off for $23,000 in \u003ca href=\\\"https://upland.me/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eUpland\u003c/a\u003e, a video game-cum-cryptocurrency that Lueth had co-founded. Over the past few years, Upland has been auctioning off various landmarks in the Metaverse, and Luether was surprised at the price that the property had reached. The player declared himself as a Bitcoiner, and said hes always been keen to get the New York Stock Exchange, Lueth told Motherboard.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eOther than having a virtual skin that resembles the NYSE, the building had no connection to the physical, real-world building. Nonetheless, in Uplands Metaverse real estate market, the location had value. The buyer might be buying the property with the intention to create a Metaverse stock exchange, said Lueth, or simply to have as a collector's item that could be bought and sold down the line.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhile cryptocurrency zealots looking to upend the traditional stock market (in a video game populated by cute and harmless-looking avatars) might constitute a good portion of the Metaverse fan base, more mainstream real estate interests are also getting involved. They're being drawn by the sudden decline in the commercial property market, and the possibility of a virtual hellworld crafted by landlords themselves.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe concept of the Metaverse isnt a particularly new idea. Its usually attributed to the sci-fi author Neal Stephenson, who first used the term Metaverse in his 1992 cyberpunk novel \u003ci\u003eSnow Crash,\u003c/i\u003e a book that was integral to early utopian ideas taken up by Silicon Valley CEOs. But the prospect of a virtual reality working up against our physical world is an idea that goes back to \u003ca href=\\\"https://medium.com/history-of-yesterday/the-meaning-behind-platos-cave-403011d240a9\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ePlatos Allegory of the Cave\u003c/a\u003e. What makes the vision shared by Upland and others from the cryptocurrency scene so distinct is the possibilities of cutting Platos cave shadows up into individual lots and then selling them back to the people chained to the wall, so that they too, can own a piece of the shadow world.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eA far cry from the damp philosophising of Platos cave, the corporate conference economy has spasmed and dried up rapidly in the wake of the pandemic, and is now turning its attention to the Metaverse, said Mike Gedye, an executive at CBRE, a Fortune 500 real estate firm. With the buzz around \u003ca href=\\\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/11/18/virtual-hqs-race-to-win-over-a-remote-work-fatigued-market/?guccounter=1\u0026guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8\u0026guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAGWy8RbQicfJ9GIhAmp6LrEmwrn4pBpoyD-d3-k7cfI8LybhPQZn6RZPFh5ABdxSHNaQ1Hkga5W9NRI2gfyztWSj6Cbc3aLpma24Oe2vsjQ8EGvEu-FUefPZSccPc7EHLZL3rjsTcGlMfEaRaAU9Qj0kt1NXIUdMMJuBjfaf4K2V\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003evirtual HQs\u003c/a\u003e, Gedye sees work, not play, as the driving force behind the Metaverse, particularly as young employees come to acclimate to the online workplace.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe biggest barrier of the transformation of work into the virtual has been a loss of human contact, Gedye told Motherboard. He was recently the co-author of a CBRE \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cbre.co.uk/services/industry-sectors/sector-insights/articles/welcome-to-the-metaverse\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ebriefing note\u003c/a\u003e that laments the end of the spontaneous corridor collision among co-workers in office environments. The Metaverse is a way to reintroduce conference networking as well as productivity-enabling aspects of human interaction in the workplace. Why couldn't you create that Metaverse for work? said Gedye. If you can do that and enhance the profit of an organization, then it's likely to be accelerated.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eLike all sound and well-reasoned financial instruments, nobody knows what the Metaverse will constitute, or how it will run. In Decentraland, another virtual platform controlled by a type of automated corporation called a Decentralized Autonomous Organization, virtual properties have sold for as much as $200,000 (in its cryptocurrency equivalent). Somnium Space, The Sandbox, High Fidelity, and Cryptovoxels are other platforms that have staked their claim for the Metaverse, all with varying sets of rules. The basic principles of the Metaverse, as \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.matthewball.vc/all/themetaverse\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eoutlined\u003c/a\u003e by former Amazon Studios strategist Matthew Ball in an influential essay about the concept, is that it be continuous, real-time, spanning across the real world and the online, and having a fully functioning economy.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__media\\\"\u003e\u003cpicture class=\\\"article__image\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 25em)\\\" https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1611588270323-screen-shot-2021-01-21-at-44640-pm.png?resize=1275:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 65.625em)\\\" https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1611588270323-screen-shot-2021-01-21-at-44640-pm.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(min-width: 65.625em)\\\" src=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1611588270323-screen-shot-2021-01-21-at-44640-pm.png\\\" alt=\\\"A cartoon llama wearing a monocle stands at a podium in the trailer for Upland.\\\"\u003e\u003c/picture\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"article__image-caption\\\"\u003eA screenshot from the trailer for Upland, a virtual real estate game with its own cryptocurrency.\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eThere has yet to be a dominant, large-scale virtual reality that can lay claim to the idea of the Metaverse. In April, the video game Fortnite was \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/video-games/2020/04/17/fortnite-metaverse-new-internet/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ecrowned\u003c/a\u003e as the new frontierthe best gamble on a virtual world where you might bump into someone at the water cooler. Fortnite, which is owned by Epic Games, held a series of Travis Scott concerts from inside of the game, with users mulling around and socializing as the event took place.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eJust as every company a few decades ago created a webpage, I think we're approaching the point where every company will have a real-time live 3D presence Tim Sweeney, the CEO of Epic, told the \u003ci\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2020-05-13/epic-games-outlines-a-fortnite-driven-more-connected-future\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eLA Times\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/i\u003e after the event\u003ci\u003e.\u003c/i\u003e Epic Games has been actively courting real estate, too, coming on as major sponsors for a property technology \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.linkedin.com/posts/holmeseddie_realestate-aecindustry-proptech-activity-6726719024278962176-OqmV/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003econference\u003c/a\u003e earlier this month. Sweeney, of course, wants Fortnite to be the platform that can provide that real-time live 3D presence. But the composition of the Metaverse is likely to be much more complex.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFrom a real estate perspective, the hope is that people will not only attend events, but inhabit, spend money, and, hopefully, work in the all-encompassing Metaverse. Simple enough. Heavy footfall areas will allow for more desirable virtual advertising space and storefronts for e-commerce. We were inspired by Monopoly, said Lueth, referring to a game that was originally created to demonstrate the horrors of extractive rentierism and undying corporate greed.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBut Lueth explains that the first steps to day-to-day retail will inevitably be real world storefronts that also have a virtual presence, blending the worlds together. Sell a bouquet of flowers in the real world, and let your customers buy a bouquet of flowers in the Metaverse.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe blending of worlds is where the Metaverse really gets interesting, from a commercial real estate perspective. I think the true value of the metaverse is when you have virtual worlds and physical worldswhen you start to have multiple [worlds] colliding, Alex Turner, a consultant with CBRE, told Motherboard.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFrom the cryptocurrency side, the future of the Metaverse is one which leads to decentralized property trading across a broad base of users, who conventionally now have a real use for cryptographic tokens. The real estate world looks towards a landlord-led model, where large property owners lead the charge, buying up the Metaverse and letting consumers wander around listlessly. Or, as the CBRE \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cbre.co.uk/services/industry-sectors/sector-insights/articles/welcome-to-the-metaverse\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eputs it\u003c/a\u003e, the Metaverse has the potential to reimagine the boundaries of what it means to be online or offline, reality or fantasy, working or living.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhile some theorists have \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.wired.com/story/to-mend-a-broken-internet-create-online-parks/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ecalled\u003c/a\u003e for online public parks, the fastest push into the Metaverse will be from mixed-use commercial spaces. According to Gedye, sites such as work-live developments and coworking spaces are already offering a comprehensive lifestyle brand. You already have a fob to get into the building, so why not an avatar and access to a parallel Metaverse workplace?\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn December, a company called Metaverse Property \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.unitedkingdomnews.net/news/267228332/top-digital-entrepreneurs-launch-metaverse-property\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e itself as the first virtual real estate outfit, backed by GDA Capital, a cryptocurrency trading firm. Metaverse Property announced that its intentions werent limited to just offering buying and selling within the metaverse, but virtual property managementpresumably with an eye towards the rental market.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFor CBRE, the promise is less in shiny things, and more in controlling the interaction between the Metaverse and the real world.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eTurner, the CBRE consultant, points out that Chinas tech scene is showing a keen interest in the Metaverse, with online shopping festivals, group buying and digital wallets (like Alipay and WeChat) helping to speed up the process. As tech writer and business strategist Packy McCormick \u003ca href=\\\"https://notboring.substack.com/p/tencents-dreams\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ewrites\u003c/a\u003e, productivity software is the next obvious move for Tencents ambitions in the Metaverse.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe move to the Metaverse will be, at the end of the day, a lot more boring than we expect. According to Lueth, Upland players spend an average of $225 USD in the Metaverse, hoping to become landlords of their own. Its small fish, considering that the internet has been dominated by rent-extracting monopolistic forces for decades now.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eApple is a landlord of apps, Amazon is a landlord of retail and Netflix is a landlord of media, explains Gedye. Real estate bros might be angling to turn the idea of virtual reality into one giant property market, but can we really blame them? Maybe not in this world, but the dream is that theyll be ready to shoulder some of the blame in the next one, wherever that may be.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eJosh Gabert-Doyon is London-based writer and radio producer focused on tech, labour, and culture. He tweets at \u003ca href=\\\"https://twitter.com/JoshGD\\\" You can think about it as the successor to the mobile internet.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":161,\"wordscount\":28,\"text\":\"\u0026#x201c;The metaverse is a vision that spans many companies\u0026#x2014;the whole industry,\u0026#x201d; as Zuckerberg put it. \u0026#x201c;You can think about it as the successor to the mobile internet.\u0026#x201d;\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae63\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":8,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Weve seen this movie before, of course: a host of Silicon Valley companies uniting to embrace a new and nebulous concept, a la the Internet of Things, that sounds both adequately future-y and freshly attractive to big picture-loving investors. The first thing he said was \u0026#x201c;I want the Star Wars universe in my life\u0026#x2026; I want to look up at the sky and see Tie Fighters and X-wings fighting.\u0026#x201d; The aim was pure, youth-inspired science fictional fantasy.\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae7a\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":31,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Of course, the broader contours of both visions will likely remain fantasiesas David Karpf\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.wired.com/story/virtual-reality-rich-white-kid-of-technology/\\\"\u003e \u003cspan\u003epoints out in WIRED\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, virtual reality, and the metaverse it presumes to enable, is a perennial rich white kid technology that has been around for decades, keeps failing upwards, and seems destined for novelty rather than ubiquity. And its worth adding that the metaverse as Zuckerberg describes ita shared 3D space where we live and work and view advertising in an embodied internetwould be an actual nightmare if it were to be designed, built, or administered by Facebook, perhaps the most notoriously drab, misinformation-littered, and aesthetically unappealing environment on the web.\u0026nbsp;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":790,\"wordscount\":128,\"text\":\"Of course, the broader contours of both visions will likely remain fantasies\u0026#x2014;as David Karpf [points out in WIRED](https://www.wired.com/story/virtual-reality-rich-white-kid-of-technology/), virtual reality, and the metaverse it presumes to enable, is a perennial \u0026#x201c;rich white kid technology\u0026#x201d; that has been around for decades, keeps failing upwards, and seems destined for novelty rather than ubiquity. And it\u0026#x2019;s worth adding that the metaverse as Zuckerberg describes it\u0026#x2014;a shared 3D space where we live and work and view advertising in an embodied internet\u0026#x2014;would be an actual nightmare if it were to be designed, built, or administered by Facebook, perhaps the most notoriously drab, misinformation-littered, and aesthetically unappealing environment on the web.\"},{\"id\":\"61030c2fc495040094beae7b\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":32,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Fortunately, we do not need to fear this coming to pass in concrete terms very much, as the metaverse vision is inherently somewhat ludicrous. But even if it is, the big swing earns Zuck and co. some credulity and latitude in the press, unlocks some venture capital for third party developers, and offers a little distraction from the myriad unresolved issues that still plague its much less exciting Newsfeedverse right now. In this sense, the biggest impact of announcing intentions to pursue the metaverse is that it may win Facebook, Microsoft, and other tech giants some leeway, a chance to deflect criticisms of its conduct and policies towards the fact that they are again in the midst of major evolution, so cut them some slack, you know? readabilityObject.title: The Metaverse Has Always Been a Dystopian Idea
readabilityObject.content:
A big shift is apparently underway in Silicon Valley. 

The company that operates the worlds largest and most profitable social media network will not, according to its CEO, be a social media company much longer. In an announcement that inspired a fervid wave of speculation, analysis, and mockery, Mark Zuckerberg proclaimed that Facebook is going to become a metaverse company instead. 

Facebook will pivot from being a website that is accessed through phones and laptops, Zuckerberg says, to a next generation computing platform where the focus is on a users presence, and is accessed through VR via Facebooks Oculus headset, or other Facebook products like Portal. I think over the next five years or so, Zuckerberg told the Verges Casey Newton, we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.

Elsewhere in the big tech landscape, Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoftat the time of writing the second largest company in the world in terms of market capitalizationhas been promoting his aim to build an Enterprise Metaverse. At a Microsoft Inspire keynote talk back in May, and on a July earnings call, Nadella described this as a new layer of the infrastructure stack where the digital and physical worlds converge.

Its not just Microsoft and Facebook. A widening swath of Silicon Valleys investor class, cheerleading pundits, and influential founders have been hyping the so-called metaverse, too. Tim Sweeney, the CEO of Epic Games, which runs Fortnite, has for years been promoting the metaverse as the fast-arriving future. The venture capitalist Matthew Ball attempted to chart its potential and explain why it is likely to produce trillions in value. David Baszucki, the founder of the gaming platform Roblox, sung its praises and underlined its import in a January piece for WIRED. 

The Metaverse is arguably as big a shift in online communication as the telephone or the internet, he wrote.

The metaverse is a vision that spans many companiesthe whole industry, as Zuckerberg put it. You can think about it as the successor to the mobile internet.

Weve seen this movie before, of course: a host of Silicon Valley companies uniting to embrace a new and nebulous concept, a la the Internet of Things, that sounds both adequately future-y and freshly attractive to big picture-loving investors. This has not stopped those companies from fomenting a new air of inevitability within the industry, or its advocates from trumpeting its imminent arrival. The metaverse is coming, one futurist enthused in Forbes in a widely viewed story, and its a very big deal. In fact, a quick Google search reveals that everyone from WIRED to the Economist to TIME Magazine to InvestorPlace.com to Verizons News Center has published stories titled The Metaverse Is Coming, which helps to offer a snapshot of who has an interest in its arrival. 

If it is coming, and if it is a big deal, then surprisingly few have paused to carefully consider the actual source of the metaverse, an undertaking which seems like a good idea, especially because that source is a deeply dystopian novel about a collapsed America that is overrun by violence and poverty. The metaverse was born in Neal Stephensons 1992 Snow Crash, where it serves as entertainment and an economic underbelly to a poor, desperate nation that is literally governed by corporate franchises. 

You will see no trace of the metaverses origins in these strategy announcements, which so far seem to hint mostly at creating and uniting more immersive digital environments in which entertainment might be consumed and work carried outand advertising displayed, workers surveilled, and branded NFTs and loot boxes sold. No trace, that is, unless maybe you read about it on your Twitter feed, where a news item about a metaverse product is likely to be sandwiched between stories about crushing health care debt or anecdotes about rampant inequality. 

So I think it is worth examining why it may be that our real-world CEOs next big high tech concept is sprung from an overtly dystopian context of mass poverty and violence; one where an immersive, shared 3D digital environment where anything goes offers most peoples only opportunity to escape from an intolerable reality. 

This imaginary place is known as the Metaverse, as Neal Stephenson wrote. 

*

The hero of Snow Crash is named Hiro, and he is a gig worker delivery driver who moonlights as a hacker, and lives in abject poverty in a 20x30 storage unit he shares with an alcoholic roommate. Hiro spends a lot of time in the metaverse. It beats the shit out of the U-Stor-It.

The U.S. as we know it has ceased to exist, and corporate entities and organized crime control whole city-states. Workers like Hiro can be killed for taking too long to deliver a pizza, and they are driven into the metaverse underworld to find extralegal work and enough money to make ends meet. The only reasonably safe places in the physical world are heavily fortressed burbclaves where the wealthy reside behind batteries of guns and gated communities. 

The metaverse, which users access through VR goggles, is the kind of 3D digital environment that should be familiar to most people who are aware of video games today, except that its massivethe majority of the metaverses real estate is developed along The Street, a huge virtual thoroughfare that encircles thousands of miles of its digital worldthere are no rules, and there are no set objectives. Users select an avatar (Stephenson also coined the popular usage of that term, too) to represent their digital selves. A higher resolution representation costs more, thus stratifying class in the virtual world, too.

And what do people build in the metaverse?

Like any place in Reality, the Street is subject to development, Stephenson explains. Developers can build their own small streets feeding off of the main one. They can build buildings, parks, signs, as well as things that do not exist in Reality, such as vast hovering overhead light shows, special neighborhoods where the rules of three dimensional spacetime are ignored, and free-combat zones where people can go to hunt and kill each other. 

the metaverse itself is a place that is addictive, violent, and an enabler of our worst impulses

Okay! So the metaverse is for light shows, people tired of existing on the space-time continuum, and mass murder. (Come to think of it, this sounds a bit like the extant internet, or just Fortnite.)

Finally, it should be noted that there is an entire class of people, users derisively known as gargoyles, who become so hooked on existing in the metaverse that they rig themselves to be permanently plugged-in, and are permanently disfigured in reality as a result. In the years since Snow Crashs publication, gargoyles have been viewed as a prescient commentary on the pitfalls of screen addiction.

Thus, in the book from which the current metaverse craze originates, not only is our world in ruins and most people are eking out precarious lives in dire poverty, but the metaverse itself is a place that is addictive, violent, and an enabler of our worst impulses. 

Its an exceedingly dark vision, if a satiric and somewhat cartoonish one (there are also lots of swords). So its a little remarkable that precisely none of this is acknowledged in the paeans to the metaverse that have emerged from founders and cheerleaders over the last few weeks and years, even as the vision of computing advancing as the world falls apart becomes all the more salient.

In the world of Snow Crash, the metaverse is not viewed as particularly coolit is necessary, because the real world has become so unbearable. Ditto in the most famous book to update the metaverses architecture for our modern, pop culture-saturated era: Ready Player One. Its Oasis is basically the Metaverse if it were written by a neural net trained on 80s movies and 00s video games. 

That book too is set in a nearish dystopian future where desperate people are driven to escape their unpleasant lives into a vast virtual environmentit is insinuated that either the Oasis is so popular because the world is so bad, or the world is so bad because the Oasis is so popular. This is a weird nexus at which to want to build out your companys future! And yet for a time, new recruits to Facebooks Oculus division were handed copies of the book as required reading.

*

Both books metaverses get at a common truism: there is something inherently dystopian in a future where humans abandon the real world in favor of an escapist and consumerist-oriented fully immersive digital one. To want to spend any serious amount of time in a metaverse, it must be made more appealing than reality, a feat which can be accomplished in one of two wayseither the world outside is already shitty enough to drive you into a glitch-prone, murder-filled alternative, or the fantasy of becoming someone else is compelling enough to consume you totally. 

Both configurations are fraught. It is easy to see the metaverse making a more compelling sales pitch in the days of pandemics and wildfires and increasingly limited real-world experiences available to the non-rich. But my guess is that the reason the metaverse vision inspires founders like Zuckerberg is not, primarily, the new network of market opportunities it presents, which is certainly therebut the personal interest in fulfilling the fantasy element. Zuck has mentioned that he has been thinking about the metaverse since middle school, when he may well have read the science fiction that described it. 

It could well be that the metaverse represents to the next generation of founders what, say, space travel and off-world colonies on Mars do to the likes of Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos. It is a science fictional construct that perhaps captured their imagination at an impressionable moment in their livesin the metaverse, you can be anyone, do anything, and vanquish foes, regardless of real-world social status or physicality. As the writer and media studies professor and video game designer Ian Bogost noted, The metaverse was never a fantasy about virtual reality, but just one about power. And now that these founders have the capital and power to pursue the fantasy, that is exactly what they are doing.

When I interviewed an executive at Magic Leap in 2018, at what was arguably the companys peak in popularity thus far, I asked him what an ideal use case of the headset would be for him. The first thing he said was I want the Star Wars universe in my life I want to look up at the sky and see Tie Fighters and X-wings fighting. The aim was pure, youth-inspired science fictional fantasy. 

Of course, the broader contours of both visions will likely remain fantasiesas David Karpf points out in WIRED, virtual reality, and the metaverse it presumes to enable, is a perennial rich white kid technology that has been around for decades, keeps failing upwards, and seems destined for novelty rather than ubiquity. And its worth adding that the metaverse as Zuckerberg describes ita shared 3D space where we live and work and view advertising in an embodied internetwould be an actual nightmare if it were to be designed, built, or administered by Facebook, perhaps the most notoriously drab, misinformation-littered, and aesthetically unappealing environment on the web. 

Fortunately, we do not need to fear this coming to pass in concrete terms very much, as the metaverse vision is inherently somewhat ludicrous. But even if it is, the big swing earns Zuck and co. some credulity and latitude in the press, unlocks some venture capital for third party developers, and offers a little distraction from the myriad unresolved issues that still plague its much less exciting Newsfeedverse right now. In this sense, the biggest impact of announcing intentions to pursue the metaverse is that it may win Facebook, Microsoft, and other tech giants some leeway, a chance to deflect criticisms of its conduct and policies towards the fact that they are again in the midst of major evolution, so cut them some slack, you know? Many tech companies have realized they are harder to criticize if they are constantly evolving their ambitions and shooting for the rafters, and a massive metaverse moonshot certainly qualifies.

But as usual with such amorphous concepts and platform aspirations, theres very little there. None of these luminaries, from Zuck to Nadella to Boz, seem capable of painting a coherent vision for what their particular metaverse will look or feel like, beyond gesturing at presence and a collection of apps, keywords, and old science fiction tropes. It is an odd vision built from a compendium of juvenile fantasies, perceived market opportunities, and overt dystopias.

Silicon Valley is often criticized for failing to anticipate the critiques of the new technologies and ideas it lionizes, and for failing to anticipate the adverse social impacts of its products. With its aspirations to construct a metaverse, it is obliviously aspiring to develop the critique itself, direct from the source.
readabilityObject.textContent: A big shift is apparently underway in Silicon Valley.The company that operates the worlds largest and most profitable social media network will not, according to its CEO, be a social media company much longer. In an announcement that inspired a fervid wave of speculation, analysis, and mockery, Mark Zuckerberg proclaimed that Facebook is going to become a metaverse company instead.Facebook will pivot from being a website that is accessed through phones and laptops, Zuckerberg says, to a next generation computing platform where the focus is on a users presence, and is accessed through VR via Facebooks Oculus headset, or other Facebook products like Portal. I think over the next five years or so, Zuckerberg told the Verges Casey Newton, we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.Elsewhere in the big tech landscape, Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoftat the time of writing the second largest company in the world in terms of market capitalizationhas been promoting his aim to build an Enterprise Metaverse. At a Microsoft Inspire keynote talk back in May, and on a July earnings call, Nadella described this as a new layer of the infrastructure stack where the digital and physical worlds converge.Its not just Microsoft and Facebook. A widening swath of Silicon Valleys investor class, cheerleading pundits, and influential founders have been hyping the so-called metaverse, too. Tim Sweeney, the CEO of Epic Games, which runs Fortnite, has for years been promoting the metaverse as the fast-arriving future. The venture capitalist Matthew Ball attempted to chart its potential and explain why it is likely to produce trillions in value. David Baszucki, the founder of the gaming platform Roblox, sung its praises and underlined its import in a January piece for WIRED.The Metaverse is arguably as big a shift in online communication as the telephone or the internet, he wrote.The metaverse is a vision that spans many companiesthe whole industry, as Zuckerberg put it. You can think about it as the successor to the mobile internet.Weve seen this movie before, of course: a host of Silicon Valley companies uniting to embrace a new and nebulous concept, a la the Internet of Things, that sounds both adequately future-y and freshly attractive to big picture-loving investors. This has not stopped those companies from fomenting a new air of inevitability within the industry, or its advocates from trumpeting its imminent arrival. The metaverse is coming, one futurist enthused in Forbes in a widely viewed story, and its a very big deal. In fact, a quick Google search reveals that everyone from WIRED to the Economist to TIME Magazine to InvestorPlace.com to Verizons News Center has published stories titled The Metaverse Is Coming, which helps to offer a snapshot of who has an interest in its arrival.If it is coming, and if it is a big deal, then surprisingly few have paused to carefully consider the actual source of the metaverse, an undertaking which seems like a good idea, especially because that source is a deeply dystopian novel about a collapsed America that is overrun by violence and poverty. The metaverse was born in Neal Stephensons 1992 Snow Crash, where it serves as entertainment and an economic underbelly to a poor, desperate nation that is literally governed by corporate franchises.You will see no trace of the metaverses origins in these strategy announcements, which so far seem to hint mostly at creating and uniting more immersive digital environments in which entertainment might be consumed and work carried outand advertising displayed, workers surveilled, and branded NFTs and loot boxes sold. No trace, that is, unless maybe you read about it on your Twitter feed, where a news item about a metaverse product is likely to be sandwiched between stories about crushing health care debt or anecdotes about rampant inequality.So I think it is worth examining why it may be that our real-world CEOs next big high tech concept is sprung from an overtly dystopian context of mass poverty and violence; one where an immersive, shared 3D digital environment where anything goes offers most peoples only opportunity to escape from an intolerable reality.This imaginary place is known as the Metaverse, as Neal Stephenson wrote.*The hero of Snow Crash is named Hiro, and he is a gig worker delivery driver who moonlights as a hacker, and lives in abject poverty in a 20x30 storage unit he shares with an alcoholic roommate. Hiro spends a lot of time in the metaverse. It beats the shit out of the U-Stor-It.The U.S. as we know it has ceased to exist, and corporate entities and organized crime control whole city-states. Workers like Hiro can be killed for taking too long to deliver a pizza, and they are driven into the metaverse underworld to find extralegal work and enough money to make ends meet. The only reasonably safe places in the physical world are heavily fortressed burbclaves where the wealthy reside behind batteries of guns and gated communities.The metaverse, which users access through VR goggles, is the kind of 3D digital environment that should be familiar to most people who are aware of video games today, except that its massivethe majority of the metaverses real estate is developed along The Street, a huge virtual thoroughfare that encircles thousands of miles of its digital worldthere are no rules, and there are no set objectives. Users select an avatar (Stephenson also coined the popular usage of that term, too) to represent their digital selves. A higher resolution representation costs more, thus stratifying class in the virtual world, too.And what do people build in the metaverse?Like any place in Reality, the Street is subject to development, Stephenson explains. Developers can build their own small streets feeding off of the main one. They can build buildings, parks, signs, as well as things that do not exist in Reality, such as vast hovering overhead light shows, special neighborhoods where the rules of three dimensional spacetime are ignored, and free-combat zones where people can go to hunt and kill each other.the metaverse itself is a place that is addictive, violent, and an enabler of our worst impulsesOkay! So the metaverse is for light shows, people tired of existing on the space-time continuum, and mass murder. (Come to think of it, this sounds a bit like the extant internet, or just Fortnite.)Finally, it should be noted that there is an entire class of people, users derisively known as gargoyles, who become so hooked on existing in the metaverse that they rig themselves to be permanently plugged-in, and are permanently disfigured in reality as a result. In the years since Snow Crashs publication, gargoyles have been viewed as a prescient commentary on the pitfalls of screen addiction.Thus, in the book from which the current metaverse craze originates, not only is our world in ruins and most people are eking out precarious lives in dire poverty, but the metaverse itself is a place that is addictive, violent, and an enabler of our worst impulses.Its an exceedingly dark vision, if a satiric and somewhat cartoonish one (there are also lots of swords). So its a little remarkable that precisely none of this is acknowledged in the paeans to the metaverse that have emerged from founders and cheerleaders over the last few weeks and years, even as the vision of computing advancing as the world falls apart becomes all the more salient.In the world of Snow Crash, the metaverse is not viewed as particularly coolit is necessary, because the real world has become so unbearable. Ditto in the most famous book to update the metaverses architecture for our modern, pop culture-saturated era: Ready Player One. Its Oasis is basically the Metaverse if it were written by a neural net trained on 80s movies and 00s video games.That book too is set in a nearish dystopian future where desperate people are driven to escape their unpleasant lives into a vast virtual environmentit is insinuated that either the Oasis is so popular because the world is so bad, or the world is so bad because the Oasis is so popular. This is a weird nexus at which to want to build out your companys future! And yet for a time, new recruits to Facebooks Oculus division were handed copies of the book as required reading.*Both books metaverses get at a common truism: there is something inherently dystopian in a future where humans abandon the real world in favor of an escapist and consumerist-oriented fully immersive digital one. To want to spend any serious amount of time in a metaverse, it must be made more appealing than reality, a feat which can be accomplished in one of two wayseither the world outside is already shitty enough to drive you into a glitch-prone, murder-filled alternative, or the fantasy of becoming someone else is compelling enough to consume you totally.Both configurations are fraught. It is easy to see the metaverse making a more compelling sales pitch in the days of pandemics and wildfires and increasingly limited real-world experiences available to the non-rich. But my guess is that the reason the metaverse vision inspires founders like Zuckerberg is not, primarily, the new network of market opportunities it presents, which is certainly therebut the personal interest in fulfilling the fantasy element. Zuck has mentioned that he has been thinking about the metaverse since middle school, when he may well have read the science fiction that described it.It could well be that the metaverse represents to the next generation of founders what, say, space travel and off-world colonies on Mars do to the likes of Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos. It is a science fictional construct that perhaps captured their imagination at an impressionable moment in their livesin the metaverse, you can be anyone, do anything, and vanquish foes, regardless of real-world social status or physicality. As the writer and media studies professor and video game designer Ian Bogost noted, The metaverse was never a fantasy about virtual reality, but just one about power. And now that these founders have the capital and power to pursue the fantasy, that is exactly what they are doing.When I interviewed an executive at Magic Leap in 2018, at what was arguably the companys peak in popularity thus far, I asked him what an ideal use case of the headset would be for him. The first thing he said was I want the Star Wars universe in my life I want to look up at the sky and see Tie Fighters and X-wings fighting. The aim was pure, youth-inspired science fictional fantasy.Of course, the broader contours of both visions will likely remain fantasiesas David Karpf points out in WIRED, virtual reality, and the metaverse it presumes to enable, is a perennial rich white kid technology that has been around for decades, keeps failing upwards, and seems destined for novelty rather than ubiquity. And its worth adding that the metaverse as Zuckerberg describes ita shared 3D space where we live and work and view advertising in an embodied internetwould be an actual nightmare if it were to be designed, built, or administered by Facebook, perhaps the most notoriously drab, misinformation-littered, and aesthetically unappealing environment on the web.Fortunately, we do not need to fear this coming to pass in concrete terms very much, as the metaverse vision is inherently somewhat ludicrous. But even if it is, the big swing earns Zuck and co. some credulity and latitude in the press, unlocks some venture capital for third party developers, and offers a little distraction from the myriad unresolved issues that still plague its much less exciting Newsfeedverse right now. In this sense, the biggest impact of announcing intentions to pursue the metaverse is that it may win Facebook, Microsoft, and other tech giants some leeway, a chance to deflect criticisms of its conduct and policies towards the fact that they are again in the midst of major evolution, so cut them some slack, you know? Many tech companies have realized they are harder to criticize if they are constantly evolving their ambitions and shooting for the rafters, and a massive metaverse moonshot certainly qualifies.But as usual with such amorphous concepts and platform aspirations, theres very little there. None of these luminaries, from Zuck to Nadella to Boz, seem capable of painting a coherent vision for what their particular metaverse will look or feel like, beyond gesturing at presence and a collection of apps, keywords, and old science fiction tropes. It is an odd vision built from a compendium of juvenile fantasies, perceived market opportunities, and overt dystopias.Silicon Valley is often criticized for failing to anticipate the critiques of the new technologies and ideas it lionizes, and for failing to anticipate the adverse social impacts of its products. With its aspirations to construct a metaverse, it is obliviously aspiring to develop the critique itself, direct from the source.
